content.title: Stacks is a sidechain
content.content: Stacks is a programmability layer with a novel execution environment, Clarity. Stacks is a sidechain, powered by a hybrid PoS mechanism (PoX) and a native fee token (STX).

content.title: No Enshrined BTC Bridge
content.content: Stacks has no consensus-enshrined BTC bridge. It does have two third-party bridges, which are both custodial multisigs. Users must trust the operators of these bridges to not steal their BTC, as they do not support unilateral exits.

content.title: State Roots Only
content.content: Stacks posts state roots to Bitcoin, but not full transaction calldata. Because of this, Stacks' state cannot be reconstructed using only data from Bitcoin. However, Stacks has a permissionless and sufficiently decentralized validator set, which makes data availability readily available (unlike with a single centralized sequencer).

content.title: Decentralized Block Production
content.content: Stacks has a sufficiently decentralized block production mechanism, but it does not support exits that circumvent its validator set. This means that users must trust Stacks validators to include their transactions in blocks.

content.title: Self-Enforcement of State Validation
content.content: Settlement is done offchain, on Stacks, rather than onchain, on Bitcoin. The validity of Stacks state transitions is not enforced by Bitcoin. However, Stacks has a permissionless and sufficiently decentralized validator set which enforces transaction validity, removing centralization concerns.

content.title: Users do not need to interact with Bitcoin to get started
content.content: Users can onboard to Stacks directly without having to first transact on Bitcoin.

content.title: Stacks nodes are required for data availability
content.content: Stacks posts state roots to Bitcoin, but not full transaction calldata. Because of this, Stacks' state cannot be reconstructed using only data from Bitcoin. Stacks nodes are the sole providers of data availability. However, Stacks has a permissionless and sufficiently decentralized validator/node set, so this is not a serious concern

content.title: Stacks requires another token to function
content.content: The STX token is required to pay for transaction fees and smart contract execution on the Stacks network. It is also used as a reward for miners who participate in the PoX consensus mechanism. The token is indirectly required for the security of the network, as block production by miners is incentivized by STX.

content.title: Clarity
content.content: Stacks uses the novel execution environment Clarity. The Clarity language is a subset of Lisp, and is not Turing-complete as a design choice. However, it is still expressive enough to build complex smart contracts and replicate much of the functionalities from Turing-complete environments like the EVM (i.e., DeFi, NFTs, etc.). Stacks is able to read Bitcoin state, due to both Clarity and its integrated PoX consensus mechanism. This allows for events on Stacks to be triggered by Bitcoin activity, or for smart contracts to read Bitcoin state during their execution.

content.title: Proof-of-Transfer
content.content: Proof-of-Transfer (PoX) is Stacks' novel consensus mechanism, based on Proof-of-Burn. PoX involves Bitcoin miners bidding BTC for the right to mint a Stacks block. The winning miner creates the block, and is rewarded with the STX block reward and STX transaction fees from the block. The miner's bid is paid to STX stackers (stakers). This system allows for STX stackers to earn native BTC yield, and creates an additional revenue stream for miners, similar to merge-mining.

content.title: sBTC
content.content: sBTC is still in development as of March 2024. It is a bridged version of BTC on Stacks. sBTC is minted by locking up BTC on Bitcoin, and is redeemable for BTC at a 1:1 ratio. sBTC is not yet permissionless, as withdrawals are permissioned by the validator set.

content.title: Faster block times
content.content: Stacks operates at the same block times as Bitcoin as of March 2024, roughly 10 minutes per block. However, the upcoming Nakamoto Upgrade in April 2024 will reduce block times to an order of seconds.

content.title: Lower fees
content.content: Stacks fees average in the order of tens of cents as of March 2024.

content.title: DeFi
content.content: The most popular use case for Stacks is DeFi. Stacks has a number of DeFi applications, including lending, borrowing, and decentralized exchanges.

content.title: NFTs
content.content: Stacks is home to a number of NFT projects, including digital art, collectibles, and indentity.

content.title: Stacks is operated by Stacks validators
content.content: Block production is managed by Stacks validators. Users trust the majority of validators to not collude and to not censor.

content.title: Users trust centralized operators to process their withdrawals
content.content: Stacks users deposit BTC into Stacks through custodial bridge mechanisms. They trust that the operators of these bridges (e.g. aBTC and xBTC) will not steal their Bitcoin assets, or censor their withdrawals.

content.title: Code is open-source
content.content: All code related to the Stacks project is free and open source.
